article:
Culture shock is the feeling of being confused a person may have when experiencing an unfamiliar way of life during a visit to or living in a new country. Culture shock can be described as consisting of at least one of the following    _  :
Honeymoon, Negotiation  , Adjustment, and Mastery.  There is no true    _  to
entirely avoid culture shock, as people in any society are personally  _  by cultural differences.
During the honeymoon period, the   _  between the old and new culture are seen with a romantic
eye.  For example  , in moving to a new country, one might love
the new food, the pace of life, and the locals' habits.  _  ,
like most honeymoon periods, this stage  _  ends.
After some time (usually around three months), here comes negotiation period where   differences between the old and new    _  become apparent and may
cause  _  . Excitement may eventually  give way to  unpleasant
feelings of frustration   and anger. The most important change in the period is    _  : the language barrier may become a
major problem  _  restoring   new relationships. 
  _   , after some time (usually 6 to 12 months), one grows    _  to the new culture and develops routines
 . One knows what to    _  in
most situations and the host country no longer feels all that  _  . One starts to develop problem-solving skills and begins to  _  the culture's ways with a positive attitude.
In the     _  stage,
one is able to participate   fully and comfortably in the host culture. Mastery does not mean    _  conversion
 ; a lot might be kept from their     _  culture, such as accents and
languages.
